user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_GetFsInfo:
```c
int32 OS_GetFsInfo(os_fsinfo_t *filesys_info)
{
    OS_object_iter_t iter;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(filesys_info);

    memset(filesys_info, 0, sizeof(*filesys_info));

    filesys_info->MaxFds     = OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES;
    filesys_info->MaxVolumes = OS_MAX_FILE_SYSTEMS;

    OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit(OS_FileSysFilterFree, NULL, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_STREAM, &iter);
    while (OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(&iter))
    {
        ++filesys_info->FreeFds;
    }
    OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(&iter);

    OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit(OS_FileSysFilterFree, NULL, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_FILESYS, &iter);
    while (OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(&iter))
    {
        ++filesys_info->FreeVolumes;
    }
    OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(&iter);

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_GetFsInfo:
typedef struct
{
    uint32 MaxFds;      /**< @brief Total number of file descriptors */
    uint32 FreeFds;     /**< @brief Total number that are free */
    uint32 MaxVolumes;  /**< @brief Maximum number of volumes */
    uint32 FreeVolumes; /**< @brief Total number of volumes free */
} os_fsinfo_t
...
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Only one use of a <string.h> function appears in the shown code: the call to memset. All other statements do not call any string.h functions (assignments, increments, iterator API calls, and the OS_CHECK_POINTER macro). The OS_CHECK_POINTER macro, as provided, expands to BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,...), so the pointer is checked for NULL before the memset is executed. The sizeof operand uses the declared pointee type (os_fsinfo_t) so the size argument is derived from the function parameter type. No other calls to memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, or strspn are present in the provided function, therefore no additional fragments require investigation under Rule 21.17.
